item.title: DHS Blames California Democrats as Protests Enter Second Day
item.description: Clashes continued for a second day in Los Angeles as the Department of Homeland Security accused Democratic leaders in California including Governor Gavin Newsom and Mayor Karen Bass of contributing to violence.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: Police fire tear gas during protests against ICE and immigration raids in Paramount, California, on June 7. Photographer: Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times/Getty Images

item.title: Milei’s Crypto Promoting Not Improper, Corruption Office Says
item.description: Argentina President Javier Milei didn’t act improperly when he promoted a crypto token called Libra in February, according to a decision by a government anti-corruption office.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Gilbert

media:content.media:description: Javier Milei

item.title: Trump Denies Making Decision to Return Abrego Garcia to US
item.description: President Donald Trump said he wasn’t involved in the decision to bring back Kilmar Abrego Garcia, the man his administration mistakenly deported to a prison in El Salvador, and suggested federal prosecutors should have an easy case.
item.dc:creator: Maria Paula Mijares Torres

media:content.media:description: Kilmar Abrego Garcia Photographer: Murray Osorio PLLC/AP Photo

item.title: Trump Warns Musk Not to Back Democrats as Vance Aims for Detente
item.description: President Donald Trump said Elon Musk will pay “very serious consequences” if the billionaire tech mogul funds Democratic candidates that challenge lawmakers who backed Republicans’ tax-and-spending bill.
item.dc:creator: Vincent Lee

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Elon Musk, ceo of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 30.

item.title: Iran Claims Access to Cache of Sensitive Israeli Nuclear Files
item.description: Iran’s state television said on Saturday the country obtained a large trove of sensitive Israeli nuclear information.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: The Azadi Tower inTehran.

item.title: Brazil Lawmakers Gear Up for Fight Over Corporate Tax Exemptions
item.description: Scaling back corporate tax exemptions in Brazil will be top of the agenda for lawmakers when they meet with the government on Sunday night, House Speaker Hugo Motta said.
item.dc:creator: Felipe Saturnino, Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo

media:content.media:description: Hugo Motta, Brazil's speaker of the lower house.

item.title: Russia, Ukraine Wrangle Over Delay to Planned Prisoner Swap
item.description: Russia and Ukraine wrangled over details of a large prisoner swap, with officials in Kyiv rejecting claims by a Russian negotiator that they were dragging their feet on the planned exchange.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Relatives and military personnel welcome Ukrainian servicemen following a major prisoner of war (POW) swap with Russia at an undisclosed location in Ukraine, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Ukraine’s capital was targeted by a Russian drone and missile barrage overnight, hours after the warring sides started a large prisoner swap that’s due to continue over the weekend. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: China Approves Some Exports of Rare Earths Ahead of US Talks
item.description: Beijing says it granted approval to some applications for the export of rare earths, a move that could ease tensions before trade negotiations between the US and China next week.
item.dc:creator: Felix Tam

media:content.media:description: A rare earth mine in Baotou, Inner Mongolia, China.

item.title: Trump’s China Gambit Belies Rocky Road Ahead on Tariff Deals
item.description: President Donald Trump has come up short on striking trade deals with most nations with just one month left before his self-imposed tariff deadline, even as he took his first steps in weeks toward engaging with China.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping (facing camera) and his U.S. counterpart Donald Trump are pictured before a photo session at a Group of 20 summit in Buenos Aires on Nov. 30, 2018. (Kyodo) ==Kyodo (Photo by Kyodo News Stills via Getty Images)

item.title: Vance Says He Hopes Musk Returns to Fold After Public Feud With Trump
item.description: Vice President JD Vance said Elon Musk is making a “huge mistake” in going after Donald Trump and expressed hopes the billionaire will come back into the fold following the public feud that unfolded.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: JD Vance

item.title: Thousands Gather for Anti-Austerity Demonstration in London
item.description: Thousands of people have gathered to "send a message" to the Government with a demonstration over spending cuts and welfare reform.

media:content.media:description: People attending the People's Assembly Against Austerity protest in central London. Picture date: Saturday June 7, 2025. PA Photo. See PA story POLITICS Protest. Photo credit should read: Lucy North/PA Wire

item.title: China Says Electric Vehicle Talks With EU Reach Final Stages
item.description: China’s commerce ministry said talks with the European Union on setting minimum prices for Chinese-made electric vehicles have “entered final stages,” although more work is required to reach a deal.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Lin Zhu

media:content.media:description: The launch event of the BYD Co. Dolphin Surf electric vehicle in Paris, France, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. The launch of the Dolphin Surf, a fully-electric hatchback, will likely strengthen BYD’s foothold in Europe at a time when Chinese EV makers have been losing momentum on the continent.

item.title: Thailand Tightens Border Security Amid Tensions With Cambodia
item.description: Thailand’s top army official designated commanders of two task forces to oversee border crossings with Cambodia as tensions simmer following a skirmish in late May.
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich

media:content.media:description: A protester holds a Thai national flag next to police officers during the protest over the Thailand - Cambodia border conflict. The Thai nationalist protesters gathered outside the Cambodian Embassy to protest over the border dispute with Cambodia demanding for action of Thailand government against the Thailand - Cambodia border conflict after the clash between Thailand and Cambodia troops at the border. (Photo by Peerapon Boonyakiat / SOPA Images/Sipa USA)(Sipa via AP Images)

item.title: France’s Macron to Visit Greenland as Trump Eyes the Island
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron will visit Greenland this month, the self-ruling territory of Denmark that US President Donald Trump has said he wants to take over.
item.dc:creator: Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron and Mette Frederiksen at the Elysee Palace in Paris.

item.title: Vietnam Inks Deals to Buy $3 Billion US Products Before Talks
item.description: Vietnamese businesses have signed 20 agreements worth about $3 billion to import more US agricultural products ahead of the third round of official negotiations set to take place next week.
item.dc:creator: Giang Nguyen

media:content.media:description: A worker uses a tractor to plant soybeans at Double G Angus Farms in Tiffin, Iowa, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Soybean futures posted the biggest intraday gain in more than three weeks on Wednesday after the US and China confirmed trade talks, lifting market sentiment over demand for American crop supplies. Photographer: Benjamin Roberts/Bloomberg

item.title: Israeli Forces Recover Body of Thai Hostage From Gaza
item.description: Israeli forces recovered the body of a Thai agricultural worker abducted to Gaza during the Hamas-led attacks of Oct. 7, 2023, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office said in a text message.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

item.title: Dutch Far-Right Leader’s Bid for More Power Risks Flopping
item.description: Geert Wilders is betting that triggering the collapse of an unloved Dutch government will position him to emerge stronger and become the nation’s dominant political figure, but signs are emerging that the far-right leader’s gambit could backfire.
item.dc:creator: Dasha Afanasieva, Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: Geert Wilders speaks to members of the media in The Hague, on June 3. Photographer: Remko De Waal/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump’s Patience With Putin Leaves Senate Sanctions Push on Hold
item.description: President Donald Trump’s suggestion that he may let Russia and Ukraine keep fighting has left US lawmakers in an awkward spot over their plan to force a ceasefire with “bone-crushing” sanctions against Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay, Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump during the G20 summit in Osaka, 2019.

item.title: Indian Delegate Says Pakistan Must End Terror Camps Before Talks
item.description: A senior Indian lawmaker said his government should not hold talks with Pakistan after their worst military confrontation in decades until action is taken to close down what he called terrorist training camps in the country, and that the US should not be involved as a mediator.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua, Swati Gupta

media:content.media:description: Shashi Tharoor in Washington, DC, on June 6. Source: Bloomberg

item.title: Starmer’s Tilt Left to Appease Labour Rebels Exposes Tensions
item.description: Keir Starmer has spent most of his time as prime minister warning about Britain’s dire finances and pushing divisive spending cuts. Nearing the first anniversary of Labour’s big victory, the prime minister appears to be pivoting to loosen his grip on the public purse.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is rethinking his approach. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Taiwan Official Discusses US Energy Cooperation at Alaska Summit
item.description: Taiwan’s top presidential aide discussed energy cooperation with US officials at a summit this week in Alaska, where a liquefied natural gas project has come into focus for potential exporting to the island.
item.dc:creator: Denise Wee, Cindy Wang

media:content.media:description: Storage sphere tanks for liquefied natural gas. Photographer: Annie Sakkab/Bloomberg

item.title: Stun Grenades, Armored Trucks in ICE Raids Spur Tensions
item.description: The Trump administration is intensifying efforts to round up migrants and it’s using increasingly aggressive tactics.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: ICE agents execute a criminal search warrant at Buona Forchetta in San Diego on May 30.

item.title: Japan Won’t Wait for G-7 Summit for Possible US Trade Deal
item.description: Japan won’t necessarily wait for the Group of Seven Summit set to take place in Canada next week to seal a trade deal with the US if the two sides can agree earlier, Japan’s top negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said in Washington DC on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Akira Matsui, Yoshiaki Nohara, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa in Washington, DC, on June 6. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: Abrego Garcia Charged With Illegally Transporting Migrants
item.description: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, the Maryland man mistakenly deported by the Trump administration to a prison in El Salvador, has been brought back to the US to face federal charges that he illegally transported undocumented immigrants within the country.
item.dc:creator: Chris Strohm, Myles Miller, Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Chris Van Hollen meets with Kilmar Abrego Garcia, left, at an undisclosed location in San Salvador, El Salvador, in this handout provided by Sen. Chris Van Hollen’s Office, on April 17.

item.title: Court Rules Trump Can Exclude Journalists From Oval Office
item.description: A federal appeals court has ruled that President Donald Trump can exclude journalists from the Oval Office, Air Force One and other “restricted” spaces based on their editorial decisions, handing the administration a win in its fight with the Associated Press over access.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Members of the media during a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Jonas Gahr Store, Norway's prime minister, not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. Trump expressed confidence he would be able to reach an agreement on trade with Norway during a meeting with Store, but stopped short of offering to roll back his “reciprocal” tariffs without concessions.

item.title: South Korea Says Trump Agrees to Ramp Up Tariff Talks With Lee
item.description: South Korea said newly elected President Lee Jae-myung spoke for the first time with Donald Trump and agreed to seek “tangible results” in trade negotiations, after the US leader imposed a 25% tariff on all imports from its Asian ally.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Sarina Yoo

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung at his inauguration in Seoul on June 4. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Pressures Fed’s Powell to Cut Rates ‘A Full Point’
item.description: President Donald Trump urged the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates by a full percentage point, intensifying his pressure campaign against Chair Jerome Powell.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during the Federal Reserve IF 75TH Anniversary Conference in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, DC, US, on Monday, June 2, 2025. US President Donald Trump pushed Powell to lower interest rates at their first in-person meeting since the president's inauguration last week, the White House said.

item.title: Trump Says Xi to Restart Rare Earth Flows, Sets Date for Talks
item.description: President Donald Trump said his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping had agreed to restart the flow of rare-earth materials, as negotiators from the two nations prepare to resume trade talks on June 9 in London.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes at the Port of Los Angeles.

item.title: Trump Gives Musk Silent Treatment, Will Consider Cutting Contracts
item.description: President Donald Trump said he had no plans to speak to onetime ally Elon Musk and added that he was still looking at canceling the billionaire’s government contracts — an indication that their public feud is far from over.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk and Donald Trump Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg, Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

item.title: Supreme Court Leaves Intact Ban on High-Capacity Gun Magazines
item.description: The US Supreme Court turned away a fresh gun-rights appeal, refusing to question the District of Columbia’s ban on large-capacity ammunition-feeding devices.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Monday, Oct. 4, 2021. The court's conservative wing offers a menu of opportunities to exploit its 6-3 majority, and give Republicans the type of payoff they envisioned when they pushed through Justice Amy Coney Barrett's Senate confirmation just before the 2020 election.
